nodes.text: Human information processing has a limited capacity often near seven items or categories, manifesting across absolute judgment, immediate memory, and attention
Information theory concepts map to psychological measurement: amount of information corresponds to variance and transmitted information corresponds to input-output covariance or correlation

Absolute judgment experiments treat observers as communication channels; increasing number of stimulus alternatives increases input information and transmitted information rises then asymptotes at a channel capacity

Unidimensional absolute judgments show channel capacities typically around 1.6 to 3.9 bits (mean ~2.6 bits), corresponding to roughly 3 to 15 distinguishable alternatives and about 6.5 categories on average

Specific measured channel capacities: pitch 2.5 bits (~6 alternatives), loudness 2.3 bits (~5), taste salt concentration 1.9 bits (~4), visual position 3.25 to 3.9 bits (~10-15 positions), curvature as low as 1.6 bits
Although capacities differ across sensory attributes, their similarity (mean 2.6 bits, SD 0.6) suggests a common limitation due to learning or nervous system design

Adding independent stimulus dimensions increases overall channel capacity but with diminishing returns; multidimensional stimuli yield higher capacities than unidimensional ones but fall short of simple summation
Immediate memory span (span of immediate memory) is limited in number of chunks (about seven items) rather than by constant bits of information per span

Multidimensional experiment results: dot-in-square (2D) capacity 4.6 bits (~24 positions); combined saltiness and sweetness 2.3 bits vs salt alone 1.9; pitch plus loudness 3.1 bits vs 2.5 and 2.3 individually; Pollack and Ficks six-dimension auditory stimuli produced 7.2 bits (~150 categories)

Binary or low-arity dimensions (linguistic distinctive features) permit expansion of recognitions by combining multiple binary judgments, e.g., 8 binary features yielded about 6.9 bits (~120 categories) in auditory tests
Empirical tests show memory span varies little with bits per item: spans ~9 for binary digits and ~5 for monosyllabic words, contradicting hypothesis that total bits in span is constant
Information transmitted in immediate memory increases with bits per item, so immediate memory limitation is better characterized as a fixed number of chunks rather than fixed bits
Recoding or grouping input into chunks increases bits per chunk and thereby expands effective memory span; practiced recoding can massively increase retained information

Smith and other experiments demonstrate recoding: grouping binary digits into larger-base symbols increased recall from 9 binary digits to 36 or more after practice, showing recoding effectiveness depends on automatization

Practical ways to overcome the informational bottleneck are (a) make relative rather than absolute judgments, (b) increase stimulus dimensionality with coarse judgments per dimension, and (c) use sequences of absolute judgments (memory) and recoding

Limitations and caveats: exceptional abilities (absolute pitch), uncertainty about upper limits of dimensional compounding, and possibility that the recurrence of the number seven across domains may be coincidental
